metadata.sermon_title: A Rich Complexity of Indispensable Pronouns
metadata.sermon_start_end: I want to take your time this morning to review what we know about pronouns. We will reach back to our learning about English grammar. I do so because the scripture lessons assigned for today suggest a rich complexity of indispensable pronouns. [...] That is why we are like the lame man healed . . . jumping, leaping, and praising God!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon violates Dekker's core thesis that a sermon is the exposition of ONE specific passage. By treating the entire Lectionary (Psalm, Gospel, Acts, Epistle), it becomes a thematic speech about pronouns rather than a deep dive into the unique word of a single text. It fails to identify what can be found 'nowhere else' because it is busy harmonizing four different texts.
quotes: the scripture lessons assigned for today suggest a rich complexity of indispensable pronouns.
The first pronoun we meet in Psalm 23 is “You.”
The second pronoun we meet is the “I” of Jesus in the Gospel reading.
The third pronoun we notice is the “we” of the church... in the Book of Acts... and the epistle reading in 1 John.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., Psalm 23) and discard the others. Focus on the specific linguistic and theological oddities of that text alone to find its unique 'current, proclamatory word'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is superficial and grammatical rather than historical-critical or philological. While it mentions the Roman Empire (John) and the Temple authorities (Acts), it lacks the depth of Hebrew/Greek insights or the specific religious history of Israel that Dekker demands.
quotes: We will reach back to our learning about English grammar.
He was executed by the empire because he cared for us in radical and deep ways.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond English grammar. Analyze the specific Hebrew nuances of 'shepherd' in the Ancient Near East or the Greek 'authority' (exousia) in John 10 to ground the sermon in scholarly exposition.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application touches on the 'consumer society of selfies' and 'neighborliness,' but remains somewhat general. It identifies the zeitgeist of self-sufficiency but does not translate this into the concrete, specific political or social realities of the local congregation as Dekker requires.
quotes: We now live in a consumer society of selfies in which it is easy enough to imagine that we—each of us—is the center of the universe.
he translates Easter power for new life into the actual concrete practice of neighborliness.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Specify what 'neighborliness' looks like in the specific context of the congregation's city or social challenges. Avoid general terms like 'Easter business'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a lecture (I, II, III, IV). It separates the grammatical observation from the theological conclusion. The hearer is an observer of a 'pronoun review' rather than being 'expounded' together with the text in a single movement.
quotes: I want to take your time this morning to review what we know about pronouns.
I have said that this is a complexity. The life of faith requires all three pronouns:
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Abandon the 'three-point' lecture structure. Allow the application to emerge directly from the unfolding of the biblical text so that the 'present of revelation' occurs.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories of misery (despair, self-sufficiency), redemption (Jesus laying down his life), and gratitude (praising God) are present in the background, which aligns with Dekker's preference for them to 'sleep' rather than be on the surface.
quotes: our lives may float off into despair because we cannot finally manage our lives without the “you” of God.
Thanks to God because God has done for me what I could not do for myself.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect. The mention of 'despair' is brief; it needs more psychological and theological weight to make the 'redemption' necessary.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions 'being lost' in the sense of floating into despair or arrogance (temporal loss), but it lacks the 'ultimate possibilities' and the 'narrow way' that Dekker emphasizes. It feels safe rather than urgent.
quotes: If we are missing the “You” of God... we ourselves might just float off into arrogant self-sufficiency... or more likely, our lives may float off into despair.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the gravity of human responsibility more sharply. What is at stake if the 'we' of the church fails to act? Use the 'two ways' to create a sense of holy urgency.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos and the source of grace. The sermon correctly identifies that man has no life in himself and points to the self-giving of Christ as the only source of new life.
quotes: the true story of our lives has at its center the self-giving “I” of Jesus
man is ultimately detached from himself and pointed to salvation outside himself.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'two natures' of Christ to the authority he has to lay down his life, ensuring the Christology is dogmatically robust as per Dekker's Thesis 7.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1150 words, the sermon would take about 11-12 minutes to deliver. This is significantly below Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth'.
quotes: I want to take your time this morning to review what we know about pronouns.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: The preacher must expand the exposition and application. The current format is too brief to allow the text to truly 'recreate' itself into a new word.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its thematic, multi-text approach and its insufficient length. By treating the sermon as a grammatical 'review' of multiple lectionary readings, it fails to provide a deep, specific exposition of a single Word of God. While the Christocentric focus is adequate and the three parts (misery, redemption, gratitude) are present in the background, the lack of rigorous exegesis and the brief duration prevent it from achieving the 'depth' Dekker demands.
strengths: Strong Christocentric focus (Thesis 7), correctly identifying Christ as the telos.
Implicit use of the three parts (misery, redemption, gratitude) without making them a dry dogma (Thesis 5).
weaknesses: Failure to focus on one specific Bible passage (Thesis 1), resulting in a thematic speech rather than a sermon.
Insufficient length (Thesis 8), failing the 'depth needs breadth' requirement.
Structure is too academic/grammatical, hindering the interwoveness of exposition and application (Thesis 4).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker's definition, this is not a sermon but a thematic address or a 'speech about the gospel'. It lacks the specific focus on one pericope and the necessary length to be considered a proper 'exposition and application' of the Word of God.
